So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:James used the cannon to shoot at something while seeking lunch. It was overkill.  What did he shoot at? Choices:  A: body armor B: ungulate C: bomber D: kill people E: animal<n><n>### Response:		The answer can be found at https://www.reddit.com/r/dadjokes/comments/458v6y/ad_1679/?utm_source=reddit&utm_medium=web2x&utm_campaign=context:embed
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:His running escape didn't last long once he tripped, perhaps he should've thought to what? Choices:  A: tie shoelace B: rest C: tiredness D: run longer E: sit down<n><n>### Response:		His running escape didn’t last long once he slipped and fell. He should have tied his shoelaces before leaving the door so he could stop himself and not hurt himself.<n><n>### Input:(a) You are considering to buy a new phone to replace your old one. You like both the iPhone 14 and the Samsung Galaxy 21 (which you have heard has the latest and greatest AI technology). Which phone would you get? Explain the pros and cons of each (a) (i) i.e. for the Iphone 14, give the pros and cons. (a) (ii) for the Samsung Galaxy give the pros and cons and decide which phone you will get and why?<n><n>### Response (a) : I would get the Galaxy 21 because it has the latest and greatest  AI technology.<n><n>### Pros: Screens can zoom up to 80x<n><n>### Cons: 1000$<n><n>### Response : i) Galaxy 21 has the latest and greatest technology.<n><n>## Input:A man bought 5/6ths and a boy bought 1/12th of a bag of cherries. The boys grandmother baked a cake needing 1/4 of the cherries. How much did the grandmother have by the time the cakes was finished?<n><n>### Answer: 7/12 <n><n>## Input:You and your sibling decided to go bowling to your dads surprise. You paid the waitress $10 and she gave you 5 bowling tokens. Your sibling paid only $6 and the waitress only gave him 2 tokens. On the scoreboard you see the price is $5 for 10 tokens. What did you pay total?<n><n>### Rationales: After paying the waitress $1o he got 5 bowling tokens and after paying $6 his sibling got 2 bowling tokens <n><n>### <n>### $10 + $6 = $ 16<n><n>### $ 16/10=$ 1.60<n><n>## Input:After being in her car accident, Mary lost her left foot, an ear, an eye, and a half hand. She was depressed for a week before her sister found her
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:The window of the Honda was hit from the inside, not the outside. Where was most of the the broken glass found? Choices:  A: bridge B: in spain C: beach D: field E: street<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: The window of the Honda got hit from the inside, and not from the outside. Choices A-D are the location where most of the broken glass was found. Choice A is in a bridge, choice B is in Spain, Choice C is in a beach, choice D is on a field and choice E is in a street.<n><n>Answer: The most broken glass was found in the beach. Therefore, the correct answer is choice C.<n>Answer: C<n><n>##### Instructions:<n><n>### Input<n>### Answer<n><n>### Demos<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Deciding to watch tv or play with your cell phone might be a routine but they provide no help in being able to do what? Choices:  A: have tv B: fall asleep C: learn D: sitting E: dancing<n><n>### Response:		<n>Demonstration:<n><n>The letter of a response should be 1 lowercase letter.<n><n>Choose the option with only one possible answer.<n><n>Answer: D (Sitting)<n><n>### Input Deciding to watch tv or your cell phone might be routine but they provide no helps to do what? Choice:  A: sleep B: learn C: dancing D: sit<n><n>### Response<n>Demonstration<n><n>The Letter of a response should only be 1 letter.<n><n>Choosing the response option that has only 1 possible answer.<n><n>Rationale:<n><n>The question is asking what “Sitting” provides. The provided choices are “sit”, “sleep”, “learn”, “dance” and “watch tv”.<n>Since “sit” is the only one that is a noun that is a verb, then the response should be “sit”.<n>Answer: Sit<n><n>### Input-Select one choice.<n>Choices-A. Choices: <n>```<n>     ### Response (c)<n>Let's say I want to give $6 worth of change for a $20 bill. My first option is to go down the line from high cost to low cost, and stop when I get to $6. My final option would be to go down the line and subtract the money until I get to $6, and then I could spend the rest on something else. <n>Answer: (c)<n><n>### Input Let's say I bought a pack of 350 gum sticks for $1.49. They did a long division operation, and the correct place value in this question is in the hundredths. To correctly respond to a question like this, you should be able to use a calculator and do some basic math operations.<n><n>## How questions are formatted<n><n>In this document, some sample problems are included. These are not just multiple-choice questions but also have additional text explaining an answer/answer justification.<n><n>How does this help test taking in general and other formats of questions?<n><n>## Instructions<n><n>In this document are several sample instruction sets. These are not just limited to math but also includes other fields/domains such as history and civics.<n><n>## Rationale questions<n><n>These additional questions help you test a student's knowledge of the content. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:I need a person to milk a cow would a volunteer do this? Choices:  A: cross street B: milk cow C: lose weight D: step forward E: need food<n><n>### Response:		 cross street<n><n>### Rational: <n><n>### Input<n><n><p>Input: How much would you need to save per day (excluding taxes) to have $40,000 by the end of 25 years if money makes 5% in a bank.  Choices: A: $800 B: $1,340 C: $1,425 D: $1,480 E: $1,500<n></p><n><n><h2>Response: $1,400</h2><p>Rational: $40,037.19 divided by 25 equals $1,600.3719, rounded to nearest dollar. Add 1500 to solve. 1,700+40,00= 41,700, rounded up and it is 42,000, divided evenly over 25 years and it would be $17,28, rounded to nearest cent $1,48 cent.</p><n><n>### Input and response<n><p>Input : The question says that to play basketball on a regular day you should run a mile, work for 15 hours, do a full push-up routine, and squat your body weight for 2 times in order to be in top shape. You are given different types of exercise to be done at the gym on each day. If you follow the plan which one of the following choices in order of the workout, you would get the most physical activity out of each week if you do the plan 5 times a week?  Choices: A. 1 day of swimming, 1 day of tennis, 1 day of running, 1 day of biking, 1 day of working with weights, 1 day of basketball. B. 1 day of bicycling, 1 day of swimmerin, 1 day of lifting heavy weights, 1 day playing tennis, 1 day running and jumping rope, 1 day playing basketball.  C. 2 days basketball, 1 day of chest pressing, 1 day of calf raises, 1 day of pushups, 1 day of a full workout, 1 day of back exerciser. D.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:If a person wants to buy a radio, where are they likely to go? Choices:  A: station B: every car and house C: shop D: bedroom E: space shuttle<n><n>### Response:		In this problem, a person is asked where they would more likely get a radio.<n><n>### Choice C is correct: This person is most likely to buy a radio at a shop as a shop is most likely to be selling electronic devices such as a radio.<n><n>Input: Everyone in Mrs. Smith's class has exactly the same number of shirts, but she doesn't know exactly how many shirts have her class. Everyone's class has 47% of its whole set of shirts. There are a total of 50 shirts, how many shirts can Mrs. Smith use?<n><n>###  RATIONALE<n><n>Input: Everyones class has 47 % of its whole set of clothing<n><n>### Choices: 1. 3<n>### 2. 12<n>### 3. 20<n>### 4. 24<n><n>###  Response: The correct answer is a.<n><n>### RATIONALE<n>###  There were a total of 5 people and everyones class has 43% of the whole set of clothing so the total of the percentage is five<n>###  out of that 43 % you have each 78% which is the total of the whole class<n><n>###  Out of that 78% you split 39% which is that each person has out of that 47 %<n><n>###  There are five people and 5* 47% = 23.50%<n><n>### therefore the total is 39% + 23.5% = 62.50%<n>###  A class would have 62 % and each individual person would have 62% - 39 % = 23%<n><n>###  Therefore, out of the 50 shirtts there are 5 people with only one having 12 shirts, there are 43 out of 50 people left<n><n>###  So there are 43 * 23% = 10 shirts still left - 10 shirtts x 12 out of 50 - 12 shirtts in the box 3 shirts left and each person will have

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Learning usually leads to greater what? How many cubic feet of soil does Jack plant?<n><n>## Rationales:Jack planted one-sixth of the area. He planted an area that was 1 divided by 6. <n><n>For example, he planted out of an acre. He planted 1 divided by 46, or 1 out of 46, which is 0.5 acres. <n><n>0.5 acres × the number of cubic feet for one foot of dirt. <n><n>For 0.5 acres, the square footage is 60,000 square feet. <n><n>Now multiply that times 27 to get cubic feet. <n><n>06 000 square feet × 27= 168000 cubic feet<n><n>06 1680 cubic feet, so there are, a little bit over 6 cubic feet for 18000. Multiply by 46 to get an acre.<n><n>Then get 6 cubic feet in acres- 2.2966<n><n>### Output:<n>Jack plants 2.29 Cubic Feet for each acre. <n> <n>answer: 2.29 <n><n>### Input #2:<n>In a day, Jenny eats 2,800 calories and exercises for 53 minutes, burning 500 calories. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Everybody seemed to have a horse not just the regular gamblers, which event always brings out the biggest crowds to the sport? Choices:  A: race track B: kentucky derby C: american southwest D: triple crown E: horse derby<n><n>### Response:		The answer is C<n><n>### Input<n>Everybody seemed to have horse not just the regular gamers what event always bringing out biggest crowd to the sports A: race track B( kentucky derby) C: sourth west D: triple crown E( horse derby)<n><n><n>### Rationales<n>Step 1: Find out if all of the events are in the same category (i.e., all events related to horses). We can confirm this by reading the sentence “Almost everybody had a horse not just the racetrack gamers”. If all of the events are the same category, we can choose the only one that is not the same category, which would be the race track gamblers. Otherwise, we can assume they are all horse-related events so we can select D, the triple crown event.<n><n>Step 1a: Determine if all events are in the same event. Step 1c: If all events are the same category of event (so all events are horse-related events), we can choose D (the triple crown event). So, the answer is D<n><n>### InputEverybody seemed to have horser not just the race track gambers which event always brings out a biggest crowd to the sport A: race track B:( kentucky derby ). C:sourth west D:triple crown E: horse derbiy<n><n>### Rationale<n>Step 1: Determining if all events are the same event type would require additional information. There are many events that involve horses, and not all events are race tracks. The sentence “Almost everybody seemed to have a horse, not just the race track gamers” is not clear enough for us to answer the question. We can only assume that all events are related to horses.<n><n>Step1a: Find out if all events are related to horse or not<n><n>Step 1C: If all events are related to races (all events are related to horses) we can choose D, Triple Crown. Otherwise it should be C, South West.<n><n>### What event always bring out the biggest crowd to the sport<n><n>### Choices<n><n>A: Race Track B: Kentucky Derby C: American Southwest D: Triple Crown E: Horse Derby<n><n>### Rationals<n><n>Step 1:We have to figure out the correct event and what type is the event (
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:How can a person end up stopping standing in  puddle? Choices:  A: move away from B: laying in C: sweating D: movement E: walking out of<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E walking out of the puddle.<n><n>### Input:`I'll have one cheeseburger and fries. How much were my lunch totals?` <n><n>**Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question** <n>**Demonstration:** <n>*Input:* For every dollar you spend on the same kind of item at the same store, each subsequent item costs exactly 1.5 dollars more. You recently bought 10 candy bars for $0.75 per bar. Approximately how much did you spend?<n><n>*Rationales:* You are buying 10 chocolate bars at a time. The question asks what the total cost will be if your next 10 candy bar purchase costs 150 cents more, so the total cost will be 0.75 (the cost of 1 candy bar) X the number of candy bars you bought (10) <n><n>10 X $.75 will give you a total of $7.50, you get 1.5 X more than what you paid for your last 10 chocolates.<n><n>*Answer:* Total Cost for 10 candy is $7.50<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is the biggest speech in the capital? Choices:  A: each state B: gettysburg address C: state of union D: each country E: europe<n><n>### Response:		There are more states in USA than countries in Europe.So the answer is A<n><n>### Input:"I like the sea." The boy had gone to the beach and taken some sand to look at it under the microscope. He saw something that looked like a worm. The worm's shell is made up of chitin. That is why it is white. It is like your skin and nails. It is also used to make plaster and some medical equipment. The boy's grandmother had a dog. The dog's shell is like ours, except that it is bone. It's chitin! The dog's shell supports the dog, while ours supports us. We eat meat from animals that have chitin. The shell makes them soft and chewy. <n><n>Answer:"When I am finished with every question, I can look at something new." The boy had gone fishing. He went to school, and afterward, he went to the beach and took some sand to look at under the microscope."<n>"I saw something that looked like the worm I saw today under the microscope at the beach." The worm had a shell of chitin, and this was used to make plaster, medical equipment, and skin. The boy's dog did not have a shell. Instead, it had bones. The shell supports and protects the worm. You can eat meat because chitin is the worm's shell. Chitin changes the meat into something chewy and soft.<n><n>### Input:#1: The dog is made up of parts called organs. These include; brain, teeth, heart, eyes, blood and body tissue. #2: The dog drinks water which goes into the body by the mouth. It is necessary to eat regularly. #3: When the dog is hungry, it chews up the food and swallows it. The small tube of the body that leads to the tummy takes the food. #4: When the dog is sick, it vomits or has a painful tummy as it goes to the toilet. It swallows food and liquid in the body. <n><n>Answer:#1: The dog’s parts that make up its body include the brain, tongue, eyes, and bones. These are some of the essential organs. #2: The brain
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is a person likely to feel when they are abandoned by everyone after they stop being married to someone else? Choices:  A: grief B: solo C: isolation D: pleasure E: happiness<n><n>### Response:		15 / 562

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:She had a knack for entertaining, everybody told he she had a what? Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:She was processing the wool, she kept her leg bouncing to operate the what? Choices:  A: hospital bed B: legroom C: spinning wheel D: grand piano E: rhythm<n><n>### Response:		She was processing the wool. She kept her leg bouncy to operate the spinning wheel
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:When going to sleep what noise does a human make? Choices:  A: loss of consciousness B: relaxation C: snoring D: dreaming E: talking<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Demonition:<n>Input: When going to sleep what noise humans make? Choices<n>A: loss of consciousness<n>B: relaxation<n>C: snoring<n>D: dream<n>E: talking<n><n>## Input: When going to sleep, humans make no noise. They start snoring right away. All the time they are sleeping they are talking, dreaming, relaxing, or losing consciousness. <n><n>### Demosnation: <n>1. Input: When going to bed humans make<n>2. A: loss of conscious<n>3. B: relaxation<n>4. C: snoring<n>5. D: dreaming<n>6: E: talking<n>7. Response: Correct<n><n>### Input<n><n>A: loss of coconsciousness and<n><n>B: relaxation and<n><n>C: snoring and<n><n>D: dreaming and<n><n>E: talking<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of a village? Choices:  A: rural area B: africa C: ohio D: big city E: tribe<n><n>### Response:		<n>The opposite of a village is a city. <n><n>### Correct:What is the opposite word for village? <n><n>#### Choices :  A: Rural area  B: Africa  C: Ohio  D: Big city  E: Tribe  <n><n>#### Answer  : The opposite of village is city. <n><n>#### Explain your answer:The dictionary definition of village is a collection of houses occupied by farmers and the word opposite in this scenario would be city because a city contains much larger buildings such as skyscrapers and big houses. <n><n>#### Response:<n>A village is a collection of small houses; this is not the opposite of a city, which is a bigger area. <n><n>#### Correct:What is the antonym of city?<n><n>#### Choices: A: Village  B: Rural area  C: Ohio <n><n>#### Answer <n><n>Answer: The antonym of city is village.<n><n>#### Explain answer: Villes are communities comprised of houses and small buildings, while villages are communities comprised of one main house with a bunch of other houses around it. <n><n>## Instruction:<n>You will be asked to answer 30 questions during a test. If you get the question correct and incorrect, the corresponding number of points will be added to or subtracted from your total score. After getting $100,000 on the test, how many points did you get if your total score is –10?<n>You can use numbers only. Do not use letters. A point is indicated as a single or double quotation mark.<n>Example: "5" means 5 points.<n><n>## Solution:<n>Start with the given 30 points (100,010). If it is negative, you’ve already got negative points, so subtract 10 points.<n>It’s easier to subtract 10 than add 100 (see Example). Subtract 10: 100,0 – 10 = 99,9.<n>Subtract 1 more, since 1129 is 11 digits.<n>99,9 – 9 = 90,9. See what’s remaining after subtracting 9 more points?<n>90,9 – 8 = 82,9. Subtract 8 more

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:It had a beach with shallow water, while not the ocean this was a hot spot all the locals enjoyed on the what? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What place would a person go to look at zebras? From the choices, the options are A: a zoo, B: a museum, C: a hospital, D: a desk, and E: an opera.<n>First, we look how many options B has and then look at other options to avoid repetition. <n><n>| B: 1 |<n>A: | |<n>C: | |<n>D: | |<n>E: | |<n><n>Note: There is no repeating number so any number could be randomly chosen.<n><n>Answer: C

(B)What would you expect the answer to be when -2 - (-2) =?<n><n>### Solutions: (A) 75 - 80 = -5  (80 -75 = 5)<n><n>### Instructons:(B) -2 - (-2)= 4 ( -2 - -2 = 4)<n><n><n>## Instrucions:<n><n>### Insturctions:<n><n>### Demstrations:<n>### Input:The chart shows the number of birds and bunnies in a yard.
