If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:John and James spent most of their time communicating with each other on their project.  The time required to communicate slowed their what? Choices:  A: static B: train of thought. C: progress D: transfer of information E: collaboration<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: Progress<n><n>### Explanation:<n>During a collaboration there are three things to communicate, ideas, skills & feedback. There was a little bit of each of these things happening among the two. What was lacking was time. There were long delays when there should have been quicker dialogue. The conversation was going backwards instead of forwards. All three of these things were lacking and caused the project to not go as planned.<n><n>### Input John spent most of his time communicating with James on a project in which they each had half of the tasks on each computer. The time required to communicate caused their progress to slow.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Step 1:John and James divided a project into separate portions. <n>Step 2 : they were tasked with completing their portions & working together to make the project a success.<n>Step 3  <n>John found that James was not working on his part of the project after completing one task. <n>Step 4<n>John thought about how it was taking forever for James to finish his part. Time is an important element of accomplishing any goal.<n>Step 5<n>They were going back and forth with each other. <n>Step 6 : John got stuck on one part so he started telling James what to do and how to do it. <n>After giving James some direction, James began to work better. This worked very well but still, they were wasting time.<n><n>### Answer: Slow<n><n>### Input When a group works on a project, the collaboration is what affects progress the most.<n><n>### Response : The group was working together to accomplish the same goal.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The speed of their project was determined based upon the ability of the members to accomplish assigned tasks, how easy or difficult each task was & how much time & attention they took each individual task. The group collaborated best when they all came together for a purpose. There would have been no group progress if it were not for member interaction.<n><n>###Input:If you have 9 apples and divide them evenly, what will be in each apples?<n><n>### Dem: <n>Rationales: We can break this down into a math equation. 3/4 = 0.75 3(0.75) = 2.25 The answer is 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:She loved buying products, she was driven by her what to shop more than any practical needs? Choices:  A: desire B: money C: time D: credit E: spending money<n><n>### Response:		 Choice E<n><n>### Justification: She loved buying products, therefore the best answer option is E. She was driven by her what more than any practical needs.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Tina is walking her dog and picks up 27 pieces of trash along the way. How much does she collect if at each stop she averages 12 pieces of trash?<n>Answer: 27 x 12 = 324<n>

Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n><n>### Response:		If the correct answer to a question is one of the choices the question has already asked you to look at, but you had no prior information on the subject, then you would choose the choice "other". Other indicates that you are simply giving a new answer to the question.<n><n>## #Solution:You found a pizza discard bin that contains only circular shaped food. There are 4.5 circular food objects on each plate. There are 4 plates on the bin. How many circular objects are there?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>#### Solution:<n>1. Count how many pizzas are on the bin: 4.5 on each plate => 4.5 * 4 plates => 18. <n><n>2. Know that 18 = 6! (n=6, n! = n*(n-1)*(n-2)*...*1) - you will divide one 2 of the numbers in to 0. <n><n>3. The first part of the equation will be 6!(6-2).<n><n>4. The second part of the equation will subtract the 1's - from each number and then add it to the (n!).<n><n>5. This is how to get the answer with 6!<n>    * 6 - 2 => {2 4 6}<n><n>5. Add in the {2 4 5} - the {2 4} goes through the 1's.<n><n>6. Add in the {1 3 4} - the {3 4} goes through to the 2's<n><n>7. Multiply from both sides.<n><n>### Solutions:Input: Jack has a 500-piece jigsaw puzzle. He completes 95% of it. How many pieces did he still have left to finish?<n>Rationales:"95% of it" means 95% of 500 is 225 pieces were still unfinished.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:How do geese normally get from place to place? Choices:  A: carried by people B: guard house C: fly D: follow ultralight airplane E: group together<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is Geese Guard House. This is the correct answer because according to the video the geese were guarding a house at night.<n><n>### Input :<n><n>> If you cut the stem of a flower and then put the flower and the stem into water, will the flower's petals open? Choices: A: No, the flower will die B: Yes, the petals will open C: No, the petals of the flower will start to wither D: Yes, the petal of the flower will start shrinking E: I don’t know<n><n>### Response :<n>The correct answer is "Yes, The petals will open but not fully."<n><n>### Explain:<n><n>* Explanation:<n><n>Answer:<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:She was sick and staying in bed the day of the event, unfortunately this meant she was what? Choices:  A: resting B: sleep more C: bed sores D: missing out E: comfort<n><n>### Response:		<n>There is a rule for each question in this section. Read the rule and write a response that demonstrates an understanding of the rule.<n><n>### Rule: When the number of people in a room is tripled, it equals 2 more than the number of people in 1/3 of that room.<n><n>### Response to: She was sick and staying home the day of the event. <n><n>The rule stated that when the number of people in one room is tripled, 2 is added to the number of people in the 1/3 room. So her home room would be 3 times the number of people she was in the 1/4 room (tripled) but only half of the room (1/3) so 2 added to triple is 6/3 so subtract the denominator and you get 6 x 3/3 = 6. <n><n>The question didn't give us any specific room so we must keep the number as a fraction. So the answer would be that the answer is 6/3.<n><n>Answer: 1. The answer is 6/2.<n><n>### Input:(A) ___________ (B) ________ (C) ________<n><n>### Response:(A) You've had 2 cups (B) You had 4 cups (C) You had half the amount of 4 cups<n><n>### Rule:(A) __________ (B) _______ (C) ___________<n><n>### Response(A) _______ (B) ___________ (C) _______<n><n>### Input:$300+$25=$325<n><n>### Response:$325<n>

Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. It is formed by the question word "what" and a specific thing, or item. <n> <n>The correct answer (A) includes the string and the last straw. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:"There are 10 apples on an apple tree.  Three fall off.  Now there are X apples."  What is this an example of? Choices:  A: park B: coloring book C: garden center D: math problem E: gravity<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n>Answer: X<n><n>### Input:<n>Rationales:<n><n>The word "X" indicates that it is a mathematical function whose solution is to be written inside the parentheses after it. In other words, the question is asking for a value.<n><n>### Response:"1 + X + 2(5X) = 783, what is the value of X? Choices:  a: 2 b: 21 c: 80 d: 32 e: 41<n><n>### Response<n>e<n>Answer: 41<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Ben was an alcoholic and was in an accident.  Because of his mistake, he spent 8 years somewhere. Where was he? Choices:  A: prison B: bridge C: locked up D: homeless shelter E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		E<n>#### Ridha K.<n>##### <n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### Input<n>Ben was in the neighbor's house.<n>#### Ridha R.<n><n>#### Rationales<n><n>### Response<n>I have chosen answer E, because Ben was not in prison, neither was he a bridge where he spent the 8 years nor home-less, and he didn't lock himself up either. He was actually in his neighbor's house while he was an alcoholic. He spent 8 years in his neighbor's home because he was an alcohol and the neighborhood was screwing him over by not letting him drink his alcohol.<n><n>### Additional Rationales<n>##### Ali S.<n><n>### Input-output method:<n><n>### Ben wasn't in a prison: Prisons would only be a choice if Ben was a prisoner. However, Ben just wasn't a prisoner like most people don't get to visit prisons since they are a restricted area. <n><n>### The bridge or bridge isn't a sentence: The other choice the bridge sounds like a sentence so it was a choice that wasn't a sentence.<n><n>### Ben isn't a home-less shelter or homeless shelter: The homeless shelter is a place where Ben was not, Ben had another home away from the neighborhood.<n><n>### The choices that were incorrect were <n>A:  prison B: bridge C : locked up D: Home-less shelter <n><n>---<n><n>### ##<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:John came to see Sam and Sam kicked him out.  Sam didn't like company.  He prefered what? Choices:  A: you B: abbreviation C: solitude D: loneliness E: alone<n><n>### Response:		The best answer is C.<n><n>

Source: https://www.differencebetween.net/language/diction/definition-of-word-even-in-words/<n><n>"Symmetrical" can be replaced with "normal."<n>Next, take the quotation marks out of the sentence because they can be ignored.<n><n>Step 1: The word "is" can be replaced with the word "are" because the distribution of scores should be even for all sections, not just one section.<n>Step 2: So far, the correct sentence, "If a distribution of scores is even for all sections, how many sections is the teacher allowed to use?" is formed.<n><n>Step 0: The question asks how many sections the teacher should use since the distribution of scores should even for all sections, if the teacher uses a normal distribution for all sections.<n><n>Step 7: Add the ending punctuation to the incorrect answer options to make them correct answers. Choices:  A: economic instability B: not noticeable C: spend more D: rising interest rates E: boring<n><n>### Response:		<n>Step1: To find if you should pick A, we will use the definition that inflation is the increase in the general level of prices of goods and services in an economy.<n><n>Step2: If you decide to pick A, there will be a decrease in standard of living because we will be spending most of our income on living which is why we should pick A if we want to keep our standard of living.<n><n>Step3: If you choose to pick B, there will be a negative impact on the economy because the country would be facing deflation. Which may end up in a very bad situation.<n><n>Step4: If you choose to go for D, there will be an increase in interest rate which will cause money will flow out of the U.S.<n><n>Step5: If you go for, we will be having an increase in the prices of goods and services which may cause people to spend more on the items causing the average wage rate to be reduced.<n><n>Step6: If you decide to choose E, which is the most interesting choice, you may not be losing any money, but you may be losing interest. This would not have a huge impact on the economy.<n><n>Answer: The best choice is E!<n><n>### Instructions You have received a cash refund check for your income taxes. Answer the question below. If the question is missing a number, leave the answer space blank. For instance, if the question asked how many apples you had, and the question was missing "apples," just leave the answer space blank and you will get full credit for the question.<n><n>## Input:You have received a cash check for your income tax refund. Your check is $2,530. Your bank charged you a service fee of $8.50 and your mortgage company withheld $110 for a payment that you didn't make for last month. If $535 is deposited into a savings account, how much money will you have in your checking account?<n>Rationales Your checking account started with $535, then $8.50 was taken out for a service fee, $110 was taken out for mortgage payment, $2,535 was deposited for refund, and $535 was put in savings. $2,536 - $110 = $2,

So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is necessary for learning by yourself? Choices:  A: exposure B: patience C: study D: cooperation E: thought<n><n>### Response:		If you wish to learn something, you would need to expose yourself to that thing. You should have patience, as learning requires dedication and thought. You should also be prepared to study as you're learning. However, exposure is one of the first steps, as you would need to know what you're learning about in order to study it.<n> <n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input:"Taking a walk outside of the city is the best exercise."<n><n>### Response:"In 2013, a study was conducted to examine what was the best exercise and the best way to exercise. The results of the study were that not only was 30 minutes of walking a day considered the best exercise, but it was also the best and only effective way to exercise."<n><n>## Response:According to the graphic shown, the study that was conducted in 2013 did actually conclude that 30 minutes of a brisk walk or moderate walk in a day was the best way to exercise, and that it was the most beneficial. While this study did not list walking as the only effective way to exercise, it did conclude that walking was the best and only effective exercise, in accordance with a 2001 study.<n><n>Answer: A<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is a characteristic of thin glass? Choices:  A: break easily B: shattering C: melt D: bend E: hold water<n><n>### Response:		Which is a characteristic of thin ice?<n><n>### Input<n><n>Which of the following is a function of a carburetor? Choices: <n><n>1. fuel injection <n><n>2. gear shifting <n><n>3. starting the car <n><n>4. reducing air<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: Your first task will be to provide feedback to a student about one of their responses. Your feedback should include the following elements, written using complete sentences. IMPORTANT: All comments must be in PLAIN TEXT only, NO ATTACHMENTS and must be at least 20 words in length. 1) Name the response you are commenting on, the section you will be grading it in, and the number associated with that response by the end of this week. 2) Clearly state the purpose of the assignment and why feedback is needed. 3) A brief explanation of why your feedback is an improvement over feedback the original response author received from you, and why you do not feel the response author needs further feedback. Be specific in your description of how you provided constructive comments/feedback and how the student responded to those comments/feedback.  *Example:* The purpose of the feedback is to show the student that I did not like their response.  *Example: *  I provided feedback and the student responded to the feedback and did not like it.  *Example:  *  I provided feedback to the student and the student responded negatively and did not like the feedback. <n><n>### Answer:For part 1, I would change the format of the response feedback to make it more constructive. For part 3, I would change the focus of the initial feedback to be more constructive. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:John loved competing because he was very competitive.  He liked being about to divide people into what categories? "due to" and "getting somewhere" would both be incorrect since "due to" describes a result and "getting somewhere" could either be reiterating the answer of the question or asking another question altogether. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where are there more telephone booths? Choices:  A: gas stations B: city C: london D: train station E: airport<n><n>### Response:		C - London <n><n>### Why I choose the solution<n>Answer choice A (gas stations) cannot be correct because the question talks about "telephone booths" but the problem does not give any information about any gas stations.<n><n>Answer choice B (city) cannot be correct because gas stations may not necessarily be in the center of cities. Also, telephone booths can exist anywhere, i.e. they can be outside of a city or even in the middle of a city, so this is not an option.<n><n>Answer choice D (train station) cannot be correct because if someone needs to make a phone call from a train station, they can easily step outside of the train station to use the telephone booth.<n><n>Answer choice E (airport) cannot be chosen because the question does not make any mention of airports, and we know that telephone booths generally do not exist in airports.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:John enjoyed his time visiting the museum.  He wanted to spend more time there, so that he could study the exhibits more.   He was a very academic person and loved doing what? Choices:  A: tired feet B: gaining knowledge C: back pain D: being bored E: pondering<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demand:<n>Input: In a year, you go to the movies 25 times on average. If you go to a movie again that you have already seen, what is the probability that you will see the movie a total of 50 different times?<n><n>Input: A random number is picked from -1 to 1. What is the probability that the number will be positive?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Demond:<n>In total, they got 33 votes in total<n><n>### Demod:<n>

How much money did Betty receive?<n><n>### Solution<n>Follow the procedure to create the correct response. <n>1. If you know the name of an operation or relationship that will be needed in your response, write down the name of the operation or relationship followed by a colon.<n>2. Then, write the total amount of money that you receive by applying the operation or relationship to the numbers of quarter, dime, nickel, and penny that Betty received.<n><n>This table illustrates an example of a mathematical sentence:<n><n>In the table, "2 x 7 = 14" is the mathematical sentence. <n>Note: To create the mathematical sentence, you do not need to write the whole number of quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies you receive.<n>1. For every operation or relationship, write down its name and put a colon after.<n>2. Using what you know about the operation or relation between quarter, dime, and others, apply the operation to find how much you received.<n><n>Input: How much money do you have? How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:When would you be able to see your reflection in a piece of wood? Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationales:The question states that you can see your reflection in a shiny piece of wood. If the wood is burnt, it will be dark and not reflect light, so the question can be ruled out. However, if the wood is carved, composted, polished, or nailed, then it will shine and thus be reflective, hence it is a correct choice.<n><n>Answer: You would be able to see your reflect in a piece of wood that is carved.<n>Answer: Carved<n><n>### Input (Writing): You will be given a word that fits a sentence. Write a sentence for the part that is given so both the whole and the part make sense. Use bold letters to write the part and strike through the sentence to show the replacement that does not make sense.<n><n>### Input<n>There are over a million books in this library.<n><n>### Response<n>A) There are over ONE MILLION books in this library. <n><n>### Rationale:The sentence is incomplete and makes no sense. Accordingly, a choice must be made. Choices A and B are incorrect, because the word there must be removed at all costs. Choices C-E are incorrect, because the phrases over a million and in this library do not fit together. However, choice D is correct, because the word over is placed in the sentence correctly. Thus, when choice D is applied to the sentence, both the whole sentence and the part make sense and do not result in a paradox. The only choice available is choice D.<n><n>Answer: There are over ONE million books in this library<n>Answer: Over 1 million<n><n>### Input(writing): Write a sentence that will fit in the blank. <n>It is hard to find _______ in a book. <n>(a) a title (b) a cover (c) a picture (d) a word (e) none of these<n><n>### Response(Writing)<n>It is hard to _______ in a [books][books].  <n><n>### Rature:The problem states that it is hard to find the title, cover, picture, or word in a book. Choices:  A: high school gymnasium B: city C: park D: use E: los angeles<n><n>### Response:		 I don't think basketball is likely to be outside the park because a park in Los Angeles is unlikely. The other locations are more likely because they all are usually outdoors.<n><n>Input: Where is basketball court likely to located? Choices A: high school gym. B: city. C: park. D: use E: Los Angeles.<n><n>Rationales: Let's eliminate two choices from the beginning based off of spatial inference, C and D. Basketball courts are primarily inside inside, a gymnasium and a city in particular have indoor courts and not many outside.<n><n>C: Parks typically have outdoor courts. The only reason why it's unlikely is because the park is Los Angeles, California. We can eliminate Los Angeles itself from being outside by using spatial inference.<n><n>D: Use suggests that basketball will be in use, which typically means indoor use.<n><n>Based on what options haven't been eliminated, basketball is possibly going to be indoor within the park of Los Angeles. This is possible because both A and B haven't been elimin<n><n>Option B: A basketball court is usually outdoors. Since A is eliminated, B is a more likely location.<n><n>Based off of logical inference, basketball courts are usually outdoors so B should be given extra consideration. We can logically infer that basketball is usually outdoors based on its physical context.<n><n>Eliminate E because it was a red herring and not given much reasoning.<n><n>For the last elimination, we eliminate A again because it's too unlikely to be on an Indoor gymnasium. That would mean basketball is both outdoors and gym, two things that don't usually associate with each other in terms of physical context. <n><n>A: High school gymnasiums are likely to be indoors so it's unlikely that C is outdoors.<n>B: We assume that B is outside and park because park is outside so any option to go inside park would also imply park would be outside. We infer this because we use a similar logical strategy to that of B.<n><n>So basketball is most likely to be located in a park in Los Angeles, California.<n><n>Answer: Most likely basketball court is located in Los Angeles, in a park.<n><n>Answer: los angeles, ca, park<n><n>### Input:(3+2)*3 =?<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. They were really what? Choices:  A: personal B: special C: shiny D: rare E: irregular<n><n>### Response:		Shiny<n><n>Input: What does the picture above show about the relative size of a 50 cent coin and a $2.00 coin? Choices: 1: The smaller value coin is worth 10 cents and the larger value coin is worth $1.90 2: The larger value coin is worth 5 cents less than the smaller value coin 3: The smaller value coin would need to be moved 190% of its location to be in the same place as the larger value coin 4: They are worth the same amount 5: The number values are accurate except that the larger value coin is $5 instead of $2<n>Response: 5<n><n># Mentor Session 05 - 08/22/2018<n>This was our 5th mentor session working on Module 1 tasks.<n><n>### Task:Rewrite the math expression as the equivalent expression below.<n>* (7 + 2 – 3)* 4 5<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Square brackets are used to show how the expression would be rewritten.<n>Since we know the expression inside the parentheses is 5, we can rewrite the equation like this:<n><n>5 4 5<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The question is asking how much the family would receive if they recycle 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers. They receive $0.50 for every 12 cans and $1.50 for every 5 kilograms of newspapers. <n><n>First calculate how many sets of 12 cans the family collected, this is done by dividing the total number of cans by 12.<n>144/12 = 12 sets of 12 cans <n><n>They receive $0.50 for each set of 12 cans so multiply $0.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the cans.<n>$0.50 x 12 = $6<n><n>Next calculate how many sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers the family collected, this done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers by 5.<n>20/5 = 4 sets of 5 kilograms of newspapers <n><n>They get $1.50 for each set of 5 kilograms of newspapers so multiply $1.50 by the number of sets to find the total amount for the newspapers.<n>$1.50 x 4 = $6<n><n>Finally add the amount from the cans to the amount from the newspapers to find the total amount the family would receive.<n>$6 + $6 = $12 <n><n>The family would receive a total of $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Step 1: The problem states that Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty. Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. Therefore, they could make 70 (the total number of strawberries picked) / 7 (the number of strawberries required per jar) = 10 jars of jam.<n><n>Step 5: The question states that each jar of jam was sold at $4. Therefore, they earned 10 (the total number of jam jars produced) * $4 (the price per jar) = $40 from selling the jars of jam. <n><n>Answer: They were able to make $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Rationales: Step 1: Determine the total number of pages in the stack. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. So, 960 pages / 6 books = 160 pages/book.<n><n>Therefore, on average, each book has 160 pages.<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:The old man was retired and liked the simple things, he would do crossword puzzle every morning simply just to do what? Choices:  A: you're bored B: pass time C: relax D: mentally challenged E: win<n><n>### Response:		answer A; you're bored<n>---<n><n>### Input1:Which best describes the relationship between the two circles on the chart? Choices: A: Both circles have equal diameters B: Both circles have equal inscribed angles C: One circle is inscribed within the other D: Neither circle has any part in the other. <n><n>### Response1: answer D; neither circle has any part in and there relationship is unspecified!<n>---<n><n>## Rationales:  Answer choices A and B are incorrect because the sentences that describe both circles use the wording "One circle is inscribed within or contained within” both circles could be placed on top of each other or on the same plane<n>choice C is incorrect because the answer uses the wording “inside” so the circles can only be overlapping, but not inscribed within each other<n><n>---<n><n>## Output:Choices: A: 400 B: 100 C: 25 D: None of the these <n><n>### Output 1: answer C, 350<n><n>---<n><n>---<n>

Since Betty picked 16 strawberries, Matthew picked 16 (the number of strawberries Betty picked) + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n><n>Step 2: The problem also states that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. Therefore, Natalie picked 36 (the number of strawberries Matthew picked) / 2 = 18 strawberries.<n><n>Step 3: To find out how many strawberries they picked in total, the numbers of strawberries picked by Betty, Matthew, and Natalie are added together, resulting in 16 + 36 + 18 = 70 strawberries.<n><n>Step 4: According to the problem, one jar of jam required 7 strawberries. So, 80 pages/inch * 12 inches = 960 pages.<n> <n>Step 2: Determine the average number of pages per book. Since Jack has 6 books, he can divide the total number of pages by the number of books to find the average number of pages per book. What task has Jack solved for work?"}<n>He used his shirt for work (A choice which can fit into multiple questions).<n><n>Answer C.<n>\strong{"If you chose B, Jack would drive train to get to work. Since Jack knows that 80 pages is one inch thick, and his stack of books is 12 inches thick, he can multiply these two values to find the total number of pages.
